inhomogeneous Cauchy integral formula

Let f∈L1(C)∩C1(C)f \in L^1\p{\C} \cap C^1\p{\C}f∈L1(C)∩C1(C). Show that the integral

u(z)=−12π∬Cf(ζ)ζ−z dλ(ζ),z∈C,u\p{z} = -\frac{1}{2\pi} \iint_\C \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta}, \quad z \in \C,u(z)=−2π1​∬C​ζ−zf(ζ)​dλ(ζ),z∈C,

defines a C1C^1C1 function on the whole complex plane that satisfies

(∂∂x+i∂∂y)u(x+iy)=f(x+iy).\p{\pder{}{x} + i\pder{}{y}}u\p{x + iy} = f\p{x + iy}.(∂x∂​+i∂y∂​)u(x+iy)=f(x+iy).

In this problem, dλ(ζ)\diff\lambda\p{\zeta}dλ(ζ) denotes (planar) Lebesgue measure on C\CC and C1C^1C1 is meant in the real-variable sense.
Solution.

Recall that by an application of Green's theorem, we have for any g∈Cc1(C)g \in C_{\mathrm{c}}^1\p{\C}g∈Cc1​(C) that

g(z)=−1π∬C∂g∂ζ‾(ζ)1ζ−z dλ(ζ).g\p{z} = -\frac{1}{\pi} \iint_\C \pder{g}{\conj{\zeta}}\p{\zeta} \frac{1}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta}.g(z)=−π1​∬C​∂ζ​∂g​(ζ)ζ−z1​dλ(ζ).

To extend this to our fff, let {Kn}n\set{K_n}_n{Kn​}n​ be a compact exhaustion of C\CC, e.g., Kn=B(0,n)‾K_n = \cl{B\p{0, n}}Kn​=B(0,n)​. Let {φn}n∈Cc1(C)\set{\phi_n}_n \in C_{\mathrm{c}}^1\p{\C}{φn​}n​∈Cc1​(C) be a bump function on KnK_nKn​, i.e., 0≤φn≤10 \leq \phi_n \leq 10≤φn​≤1 and φn=1\phi_n = 1φn​=1 on a neighborhood of KnK_nKn​. Let ψ1=φ1\psi_1 = \phi_1ψ1​=φ1​ and ψn=φn−φn−1\psi_n = \phi_n - \phi_{n-1}ψn​=φn​−φn−1​ for n≥2n \geq 2n≥2 so that ψn\psi_nψn​ is 000 on a neighborhood of Kn−1K_{n-1}Kn−1​. Since Kn⊆Kn+1K_n \subseteq K_{n+1}Kn​⊆Kn+1​ for each nnn, it follows that this sum is locally finite. Hence, at z∈KNz \in K_Nz∈KN​, we have

∑n=1∞ψn(z)=φ1(z)+∑n=2N(φn(z)−φn−1(z))=φN(z)=1,\sum_{n=1}^\infty \psi_n\p{z} = \phi_1\p{z} + \sum_{n=2}^N \p{\phi_n\p{z} - \phi_{n-1}\p{z}} = \phi_N\p{z} = 1,n=1∑∞​ψn​(z)=φ1​(z)+n=2∑N​(φn​(z)−φn−1​(z))=φN​(z)=1,

so {ψn}n\set{\psi_n}_n{ψn​}n​ is a locally finite partition of unity. Thus,

u(z)=−12π∬C∑n=1∞ψn(ζ)f(ζ)ζ−z dλ(ζ)=−12π∬C∑n=1∞ψn(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)ζ dλ(ζ)(ζ↦ζ−z)=−12π∑n=1∞∬Cψn(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)ζ dλ(ζ),\begin{aligned} u\p{z} &= -\frac{1}{2\pi} \iint_\C \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\psi_n\p{\zeta}f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta} \\ &= -\frac{1}{2\pi} \iint_\C \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\psi_n\p{\zeta + z}f\p{\zeta + z}}{\zeta} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta} && \p{\zeta \mapsto \zeta - z} \\ &= -\frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \iint_\C \frac{\psi_n\p{\zeta + z}f\p{\zeta + z}}{\zeta} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta}, \end{aligned}u(z)​=−2π1​∬C​n=1∑∞​ζ−zψn​(ζ)f(ζ)​dλ(ζ)=−2π1​∬C​n=1∑∞​ζψn​(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)​dλ(ζ)=−2π1​n=1∑∞​∬C​ζψn​(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)​dλ(ζ),​​(ζ↦ζ−z)​

since after the change of variables, the sum is finite for each z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C. Again by local finiteness, because ψn,f\psi_n, fψn​,f are C1C^1C1, it follows that uuu is also C1C^1C1. Similarly, local finiteness allows us to interchange the derivative and the sum, and because f∈L1(C)f \in L^1\p{\C}f∈L1(C) and each ψn\psi_nψn​ is compactly supported, we may differentiate under the integral sign and apply change of variables freely:

∂u∂z‾(z)=−1π∑n=1∞∂∂z‾∬Cψn(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)ζ dλ(ζ)=−1π∑n=1∞∬C∂(ψnf)∂ζ‾(ζ+z)1ζ dλ(ζ)=−1π∑n=1∞∬C∂(ψnf)∂ζ‾(ζ)1ζ−z dλ(ζ)(ζ↦ζ+z)=∑n=1∞ψn(z)f(z)(ψnf∈Cc1)=f(z),\begin{aligned} \pder{u}{\conj{z}}\p{z} &= -\frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \pder{}{\conj{z}} \iint_\C \frac{\psi_n\p{\zeta + z}f\p{\zeta + z}}{\zeta} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta} \\ &= -\frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \iint_\C \pder{\p{\psi_nf}}{\conj{\zeta}}\p{\zeta + z} \frac{1}{\zeta} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta} \\ &= -\frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \iint_\C \pder{\p{\psi_nf}}{\conj{\zeta}}\p{\zeta} \frac{1}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\lambda\p{\zeta} && \p{\zeta \mapsto \zeta + z} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \psi_n\p{z} f\p{z} && \p{\psi_n f \in C_{\mathrm{c}}^1} \\ &= f\p{z}, \end{aligned}∂z∂u​(z)​=−π1​n=1∑∞​∂z∂​∬C​ζψn​(ζ+z)f(ζ+z)​dλ(ζ)=−π1​n=1∑∞​∬C​∂ζ​∂(ψn​f)​(ζ+z)ζ1​dλ(ζ)=−π1​n=1∑∞​∬C​∂ζ​∂(ψn​f)​(ζ)ζ−z1​dλ(ζ)=n=1∑∞​ψn​(z)f(z)=f(z),​​(ζ↦ζ+z)(ψn​f∈Cc1​)​

since we had a partition of unity.
